'''Martin Edward Gurule''' (November 7, 1969 - November 27, 1998) was an [[United States|American]] prisoner who, in 1998, successfully escaped from [[death row]] in [[Texas]]. It was the first successful breakout from Texan death row since [[Raymond Hamilton]] was broken out by [[Bonnie and Clyde]] on January 16, 1934.
== Life == Martin Gurule was a [[Latino]] who was raised by his father and grandmother. His mother died shortly before his first birthday. He attended [[W. B. Ray High School]] in [[Corpus Christi, Texas|Corpus Christi]] and cared for intellectually disabled patients at [[Texas state supported living centers|Corpus Christi State School]], an institution run by the Texas Department of Mental Health and Mental Retardation. His 23-year-old girlfriend, Malisa Smith, worked on the checkout at the U & I restaurant in Corpus Christi.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/28/us/texas-death-row-inmate-pulls-off-escape.html|title=Texas Death Row Inmate Pulls Off Escape|last=Lyman|first=Rick|date=1998-11-28|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-01-16|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
== Crimes == On October 12, 1992, Gurule entered U & I late at night and fatally shot restaurant co-owner Mike Piperis and employee Anthony Staton. Gurule claimed that Piperis had ordered him to come to the restaurant that night because Piperis wanted to discuss an accusation of Gurule committing [[Tax evasion in the United States|tax evasion]]. Then, Gurule claimed, Piperis attacked him and Gurule used his firearm in [[Right of self-defense|self-defense]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1998/dec/04/news/mn-50595|title=Escaped Death Row Inmate Found Dead|last=KOLKER|first=CLAUDIA|date=1998-12-04|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-01-16|last2=HART|first2=LIANNE|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref>
Investigators contradicted Gurule's version of events. They alleged that Staton was sitting on a chair when he was shot in the back of the head. Piperis was found kneeling against a chair in front of an open [[safe]], and had also been shot in the back of the head. It was also discovered that Gurule's girlfriend, Malisa Smith, had been fired from her job at the restaurant in the week before the killings. The prosecution alleged that Gurule and Smith had jointly planned to rob the restaurant. It was also noted that Gurule had convictions dating back to 1986 for [[credit card fraud]], theft and two robberies. [[Nueces County, Texas|Nueces County]] [[District attorney|District Attorney]] Carlos Valdéz called the killings a "crime that had had been building up over several years".<ref name=":0" />
In July 1993, Martin Gurule was convicted of first degree murder and [[Capital punishment in Texas|sentenced to death]], while Smith was sentenced to 25 years in jail. Gurule was transferred to the [[Ellis Unit|Elis Unit]] in an [[unincorporated area]] of [[Walker County, Texas|Walker County]]. It is the only unit in Texas that has death row for male inmates. Gurule was selected for the Work Capable Program, together with around 150 other death row inmates. This was a trial program that allowed selected death row inmates to move relatively freely outside their cells, to have contact with other non-death row inmates and to carry out supervised work within the prison.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/1997/07/shadow-figures-portrait-life-texas-death-row/|title=Shadow Figures: A Portrait of Life on Texas Death Row|work=Mother Jones|access-date=2018-01-16|language=en-US}}</ref> His appeal against the death penalty was denied a year before his escape.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/04/us/death-row-escapee-found-dead.html|title=Death Row Escapee Found Dead|last=Lyman|first=Rick|date=1998-12-04|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-01-16|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
== Escape == During a [[Thanksgiving dinner]] on November 26, 1998, Martin Gurule and six other death row inmates hid in a [[recreation room]]. Prior to leaving their cells for the dinner, they had placed cushions and sheets in their beds in such a way that the guards would not suspect anything was amiss. They also darkened their prison uniforms with [[marker pen]]s so that they would be less visible at night. After the cells were locked for the night, they broke through a door to the recreational yard and then through a separating fence. Once they reached the main prison yard, they scaled the roof of a building and waited for complete darkness.<ref name=":1" />
Shortly after midnight, guards at a post spotted the escapees climbing, immediately raising the alarm and opening fire. At this point, all six of Gurule's co-escapees surrendered, but Gurule ran approximately 100 ft over an open piece of land, scaled a [[Barbed wire|barbed-wire]] fence, ran another 70 ft across a clearing, scaled a second barbed-wire fence and disappeared into the darkness outside the prison boundary, despite the guards firing 18 shots at him.<ref name=":1" />
More than 500 officers from surrounding towns, cities and counties took part in the manhunt, which was supported by [[Detection dog|sniffer dogs]], boats and helicopters. [[Governor of Texas|Governor]] [[George W. Bush]] additionally called in the [[Texas Ranger Division|Texas Rangers]] and announced a 5,000-dollar reward for information leading to Gurule's capture.
Seven days later, two fishermen found Gurule's body in a tributary of the [[Trinity River (Texas)|Trinity River]] near [[Huntsville, Texas|Huntsville]].<ref name=":2" /> Gurule was wearing several layers of clothing and rolled up newspapers and cardboard to protect him while scaling the prison's barbed-wire fences. The autopsy revealed that he had sustained a gunshot in the back, causing him to [[Drowning|drown]] in the river. His time of death was backdated to November 27, meaning that he died on the night of his escape. Investigators believe that he jumped into the river to remove traces that could allow sniffer dogs to locate him, and then drowned due to the severity of his gunshot wound preventing him from being able to get out of the river.<ref name=":0" />
As a direct result of Gurule's escape, the [[Texas Department of Criminal Justice]] relocated its death row in March 1999 to the Terrell Unit (now renamed the [[Allan B. Polunsky Unit]]), in [[West Livingston, Texas|West Livingston]], [[Polk County, Texas|Polk County]]. The Work Capable Program was discontinued.
== Co-escapees == * Eric Dewayne Cathey (27), on death row since 1997 * James Edward Clayton (32), executed May 25, 2000 * Henry Earl Dunn (24), executed February 6, 2003 * [[Gustavo Julian Garcia]] (26), executed February 17, 2016 * Howard Guidry (22), on death row since 1997 * [[Ponchai Wilkerson]] (27), executed March 14, 2000

'''Melvin Charney''' (28 August 1935<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gallery.ca/en/see/collections/artist.php?iartistid=975 |title=Collections : Melvin Charney|publisher=The National Gallery of Canada |date= |accessdate=2012-09-19}}</ref> – 17 September 2012<ref name=obit>{{cite web|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/montrealgazette/obituary.aspx?n=melvin-charney&pid=159979752 |title=Melvin Charney Obituary: The Montreal Gazette|publisher=Legacy.com |date= |accessdate=2012-09-19}}</ref>) was a Canadian artist and architect.<ref name="Charney 2000">{{cite book |title='Tracking images : Melvin Charney, un dictionnaire' |last=Charney |first=Melvin |publisher=Centre canadien d'architecture/Canadian Centre for Architecture |year=2000}}</ref>
[[File:Melvin Charney Jardin de sculptures.jpg|thumb|Charney's sculpture garden at the Canadian Centre for Architecture]] [[File:Montreal Berri-UQAM.jpg|thumb|''Skyscraper, Waterfall, Brooks — A Construction'']] He was born in 1935, and grew up in a working-class family in [[The Plateau]] neighbourhood of Montreal, the eldest of three sons of Hyman and Fanny Charney. Fanny was originally from what is now [[Belarus]], and worked in a sewing factory. Hyman Charney was from Poland, and worked as a paint salesman as well as an accomplished woodworker and decorator, creating doors for synagogues and churches. Hyman was also interested in visual arts, and from a young age, Melvin took Saturday classes at the [[Montreal Museum of Fine Arts]]. Later in his childhood the family was able to afford to move to the edge of [[Outremont]].<ref name=GlobeObit>{{cite news|author=Fitterman, Lisa|date=29 September 2012|title='He made evident what is evident': Montreal artist believed architectural designs should be created with an understanding of urban and social contexts|newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]]|page=S12}}</ref>
He studied architecture at [[McGill University]] and [[Yale University]], and worked in Paris and New York before returning to Montreal in 1964, where he opened his architecture practice and began teaching at the [[Université de Montréal]].<ref name=Curran>{{cite news|last=Curran|first=Peggy|title=Melvin Charney: A towering figure in Montreal architecture|url=https://montrealgazette.com/travel/towering+figure+Montreal+architecture/7268289/story.html|accessdate=22 September 2012|newspaper=[[Montreal Gazette]]|date=19 September 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120923004558/http://www.montrealgazette.com/travel/towering+figure+Montreal+architecture/7268289/story.html|archivedate=23 September 2012|df=}}</ref>
Charney submitted a design for the Canadian pavilion at [[Expo 70]] which would be fashioned from construction cranes and scaffolding. His submission, while not successful, signalled Charney's shift away from building design to [[public art]]. His depiction of historic buildings demolished to make way for [[Expo 67]] and the [[Montreal Olympic Games]] in the short-lived [[Corrid’art]] exhibit is reported to be a primary reason why mayor [[Jean Drapeau]] ordered the exhibition demolished. Notable public art works by Charney in Montreal include the [[sculpture garden]] at the [[Canadian Centre for Architecture]] and the sculpture ''Skyscraper, Waterfall, Brooks — A Construction'' at [[Place Émilie-Gamelin]], both constructed after Drapeau left office.<ref name=Curran/>
In 2003, he was named a Chevalier (Knight) of the [[Ordre national du Québec]] for his outstanding accomplishments and contributions to the growth of Quebec. In 2006, he was named a Commandeur of the [[Ordre des Arts et des Lettres]] by the government of France for his contributions to culture.<ref name=obit/> He was married to writer [[Ann Charney]].<ref name=Curran/>

[[St. Louis University School of Law]] ([[Juris Doctor|J.D.]]) | nationality = United States}} '''Michael Joseph Reagan''' (born 1954) is the [[United States federal judge|Chief United States District Judge]] of the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of Illinois]]. ==Education and career== {{unsourced|section|date=August 2017}} Born in [[Albuquerque, New Mexico]], Reagan received a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree from [[Bradley University]] in 1976 and a [[Juris Doctor]] from [[St. Louis University School of Law]] in 1980. He was a [[law clerk]] in the Office of the Appellate Defender for the Fifth Appellate District of Illinois in 1978. He was in private practice from 1979 to 2000, also working as an instructor in business law, [[Belleville Area College]] from 1980-83 and as an adjunct assistant professor of law at [[St. Louis University]] from 1982-88. He was an assistant [[public defender]] for [[St. Clair County, Illinois]] from 1996 to 2000. ==Federal judicial service== On May 11, 2000, Reagan was nominated by President [[Bill Clinton]] to a new seat on the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of Illinois]] new seat created on November 2, 2002 by 116 Stat. 1758.Seat superseded Seat 6 on October 11, 2001 pursuant to 71 Stat. 586. Seat made permanent on November 2, 2002 by 116 Stat. 1758 Reagan was confirmed by the [[United States Senate]] on October 3, 2000, and received his commission on October 13, 2000. He was designated Chief Judge on October 1, 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.ilsd.uscourts.gov/TheCourt.aspx|title=The Court: Additional Historical Highlights|publisher=[[United States District Court for the Southern District of Illinois]]}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Notes== {{Reflist|group="Note"}} ==Sources== *[https://www.fjc.gov/history/judges/reagan-michael-joseph Biodata], fjc.gov; accessed August 29, 2017. {{s-start}} {{s-legal}} {{s-bef|before=Seat established by 71 Stat. 586}} {{s-ttl|title={{nowrap|Judge of the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of Illinois]]}}|years=2000–present}} {{s-inc|rows=2}} {{s-bef|before=[[David R. Herndon]]}} {{s-ttl|title={{nowrap|Chief Judge of the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of Illinois]]}}|years=2014–present}} {{s-end}} {{United States 7th Circuit district judges}} {{United States Judicial Conference}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Reagan, Michael Joseph}} [[Category:1954 births]] [[Category:Bradley University alumni]] [[Category:Judges of the United States District Court for the Southern District of Illinois]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Albuquerque, New Mexico]] [[Category:Public defenders]] [[Category:Saint Louis University alumni]] [[Category:United States district court judges appointed by Bill Clinton]] [[Category:Date of birth missing (living people)]]

Црногорци у Србији |image = flag_of_montenegrins_in_serbia.png |image_caption = Flag of the National Council of the Montenegrin Minority in Serbia |population = '''38,527''' (2011) |region1 = {{flag|Vojvodina}} |pop1 = 22,141 (1.15%) |ref1 = |region2 = {{flagicon image|Flag of Belgrade.svg}} [[Belgrade]] |pop2 = 9,902 |ref2 = |region3 = |pop3 = |ref3 = |region4 = |pop4 = |ref4 = |languages = [[Montenegrin language|Montenegrin]]{{cite web|title=Nacionalni savjet crnogorske nacionalne manjine|url=http://www.mne.rs}} and [[Serbian language|Serbian]] |religions = Orthodox Christians |related = [[Serbs]] |footnotes = }} The '''Montenegrins of Serbia''' ([[Montenegrin language|Montenegrin]] and [[Serbian language|Serbian]]: ''Crnogorci u Srbiji /'' Црногорци у Србији) are a [[national minority]] in the country. According to the 2011 census, there are 38,527http://popis2011.stat.rs/?lang=en ethnic [[Montenegrins]] in [[Serbia]]. They are the sixth largest ethnic community in the [[Vojvodina]] province. ==Geography== The largest concentration of Montenegrins in Vojvodina could be found in the municipalities of [[Vrbas (city)|Vrbas]] (24.79%), [[Mali Iđoš]] (20.83%), and [[Kula (Vojvodina)|Kula]] (16.34%). Settlements in Vojvodina with absolute or relative Montenegrin majority are: [[Lovćenac]] in the [[Mali Iđoš]] municipality with 56.86% Montenegrins, [[Kruščić]] in the [[Kula (Vojvodina)|Kula]] municipality with 32.64% Montenegrins, and [[Savino Selo]] in the [[Vrbas (city)|Vrbas]] municipality with 38.20% Montenegrins. Formerly, the village of [[Bačko Dobro Polje]] in the [[Vrbas (city)|Vrbas]] municipality also had a Montenegrin majority (According to the 1971 census, Montenegrins comprised 55.39% of population of this village, while according to the 2002 census, the current population of the village is composed of 57.17% Serbs and 38.18% Montenegrins). ==Demographics== [[File:Lovcenac, Sveti Petar Cetinjski.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Village of [[Lovćenac]], Sveti Petar Cetinjski Church]] {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Montenegrins ! % |- | 1948 || 74,860 || 1.15% |- | 1953 || 86,061 || 1.23% |- | 1961 || 104,753 || 1.37% |- | 1971 || 125,260 || 1.48% |- | 1981 || 147,466 || 1.58% |- | 1991 || 139,299 || 1.42% |- | 1991 (excl. Kosovo)|| 118,934 || 1.52% |- | 2002 (excl. Kosovo)|| 69,049 || 0.92% |- | 2011 (excl. Kosovo) || 38,527 || 0.5% |} In Vojvodina, the number of Montenegrins, according to 1948-2011 censuses: 1948: 30,589 (1.9%); 1953: 30,516 (1.8%); 1961: 34,782 (1.9%); 1971: 36,416 (1.9%); 1981: 43,304 (2.1%); 1991: 47,289 (2.3%); 2002: 35,513 (1.75%); 2011: 22,141 (1.15%). ==Culture== Montenegrins in Serbia speak [[Serbian language|Serbian]] or [[Montenegrin language|Montenegrin]] and the vast majority are adherents of the [[Serbian Orthodox Church]].
